conversation.content: So, um, have you ever done that thing where you, [high-pitched], like, pretend to be a local in, you know, a tourist spot?
Oh god, actually, yes! I once spent, hmm, an entire afternoon in Times Square pretending I knew where everything was, basically, giving completely made-up directions to other tourists.
That's evil! I love it!
The thing is, everyone seemed so, well, grateful for any help, and I mean, most of them probably ended up somewhere interesting anyway, right?
Wait wait wait, so you were just, er, sending people on, like, random adventures through Manhattan? That's, honestly, kind of brilliant!
Look, I figured, you know, getting lost is half the fun of traveling anyway, and, uhh, they wanted authentic New York experiences, so really, I was helping!
Did anyone ever come back and yell at you?
Actually, one couple came back, but here's the thing, they were thrilled because they'd, um, stumbled onto this amazing hole-in-the-wall dumpling place, so they thanked me!
No way! That's— okay so, that's literally, I mean, the best possible outcome, err, from giving fake directions!
Right? Sometimes the universe just [sleepily] works out that way, though I did feel slightly guilty when this sweet elderly couple asked about the subway.
Oh no, what did you tell them?
Well, I basically just pointed them toward, you know, the nearest entrance and said "good luck," which, honestly, isn't that different from what actual New Yorkers do.
True! Nobody really knows how the subway works anyway!
The best part is, um, when actual locals started joining in, like, they'd overhear me giving these ridiculous directions and, anyway, just play along completely straight-faced.
This is why I [confidently] always use my phone for directions now!
Smart move, though honestly, half the adventure stories I have are from, well, getting completely lost and, er, ending up in the weirdest places imaginable.
Like that time you, uhh, ended up at that wedding in, I guess, Prague? Was it, actually, Prague?
Budapest! And yes, somehow I went from, you know, looking for a bathroom to being handed champagne and, basically, dancing with someone's grandmother for, um, two hours straight.
How do you even— I mean, like, how does that happen? Were you just, err, too polite to leave or, honestly, what?
The thing is, once you're holding the champagne and, well, the grandmother has your arm, you're basically committed, and anyway, Hungarian weddings are, actually, incredibly fun!
